review_blob: Received as a gift for a favour, 0,33l bottle. Dark brown slightly hazy colour, small beige head, moderate lacing. Heavyish malty aroma of chocolate, nuts, some coffee and toast. Some undistinguishable hops in the background balancing it a bit. Taste is sweetish at first, turning into a moderately bitter finish with a hint of astringency. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, moderate carbonation. Quite a nice beer with the reindeer meat soup I had it with. Possibly not complex enough to be enjoyed on its own, but very drinkable in any case.

500ml bottle. Clear Gold colour, small mostly vanishing white head, little lacing. Aroma is sweetish moderate to heavy tropical fruit and citric hops with some bisquity malt. Taste is moderately sweet at first turning into a lingering bitter finish with a mineral feel. Light to medium body, average carbonation slck mouthfeel. One of the better single-hop Citra ales I recently tasted.

355ml bottle. Hazy pale gold colour, small fully vanishing white head, no lacing.Moderately hoppy, citrusy aroma with a bit of spruce,neglible amounts of malt and a fair bit of pepper and a bit of fruity esters. Taste is initially balanced and a bit sweetish, turning quickly to a moderately bitter and longish finish. Soft carbonation, light body, thin texture. Quite refreshing and somewhat interesting, though there are ales of this strength with more aroma depth. Also rather unbalanced.

330ml bottle, light copper colour, small mostly vanishing white head, no lacing. Moderately malty aroma of bisquit and caramel with moderate lemony, resiny and herbal hops. Taste is initially moderately sweet with a shortish moderately bitter bite in the finish with a bit of minerals. Medium body, almost watery mouthfeel, lively carbonation. A fairly pleasant easily approachable pale ale, hopping is nowhere near IPA of any kind though. About as interesting as a well-made bulk lager.
beer_name: Sinebrychoff Nikolai Brewmasters Collection India Pale Ale

review_blob: 500ml bottle from Vyborg. Clear deep gold colour, small frothy mostly vanishing white head, zero lacing. Light malty aroma of grain and white bread, light grassy hops. Taste is slightly sweet at firs turning into a lightly bitter finish with a bit of sourness/astringency. Light body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Not exactly interesting, though somewhat above most other supermarket stuff from Russia.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Vyborg, clear gold colour, small fizzy quickly vanishing white head, no lacing. Moderately malty aroma of cereal, meal and bisquit with some hints of floral hops. Taste is less sweet than aroma and slightly bitter towards the finish which has a rather astrigent feel. Medium body, lively carbonation, slick mouthfeel. Not interesting at all and not good even for a bulk lager.

500ml bottle from a shop in st. Petersburg. Pale yellow clear colour, small frothy mostly lasting white head, good lacing. Moderately to heavily malty aroma of grain and biscuit with a hint of hops and some minor fruitiness. Taste is initially slightly sweet, turning into a lightly bitter but somewhat long lasting finish with a hint of alcohol. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation.
Not much hops, a fair bit of malt character and even some non-awful hints of yeast esters. Not amazing but way better than what was expected.

330ml bottle, hazy light orange colour, medium frothy mostly lasting head, good lacing. Heavyish hoppy aroma of grapefruit and flower with some resiny hints and some grain and caramel in the background. Taste is initially bittersweet, turning into a long bitter finish, medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Nicely refreshing and sharply bitter ale without going overboard, couldve maybe had a bit more aroma depth and a little more maltiness to back it up but anyways among the better craft ales from Finland that I had.

500ml bottle from supermarket near Warsaw, pale yellow colour, small mostly vanishing white head, no lacing. Mildly malty aroma of grain and meal with light floral hops. Taste is initially sweetish, turnin into a bittersweet finish, light body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Generic lager with a slightly more noticeable hop aroma, not particularly interesting

500ml bottle from a supermarket in Ostrava, clear deep golden colour, small white mostly vanishing white head, not much lacing. Lightish malty aroma of grain and bisquit with moderate herbal and floral hops. Taste is initially bittersweet with a bit of minerals and turns into a moderately bitter finish. Medium body, dryish mouthfeel, average carbonation.
Not insanely complex, but quite a bit of character for a mildish lager and beats nearly all bigger Czech brands. Pretty close to the ideal lawnmower beer.

330ml bottle from a supermarket in Brno, almost non-existant white head, no lacing. Moderately to heavily malty aroma of grain, bread and caramel with lightish floral hops and a hint of caramel. Taste is sweetish at first, with a ligthly bitter finish with an alcoholic feel. Full body, oily mouthfeel, light carbonation. A step up from the usual booze-lager, but nothing too interesting

500ml bottle from supermarket near Brno. Clear gold colour, small mostly vanishing white head, little lacing. Moderately hoppy aroma of grass with light grains and white bread. Taste is initially mildly sweet with a hint of sourness, turning into a moderately bittersweet finish. Light to medium body, average carbonation, dryinsh mouthfeel. 
Fairly drinkable light lager, not exactly amazing but a really good lawnmower beer.

500ml bottle from Torfyanovka, Russia. Clear light golden colour, small fizzy mostly vanishing white head, some lacing. Light malty aroma of hay, corn and a hint of caramel with light herbal hops. Taste is initially lightly acidic with a hint of sweetness turning into a lightly bittersweet finish with a somewhat chalky feel. Light body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Noticeably different from other Baltika lagers, hop aroma was ok but corn was a bit too noticeable and taste wasnt all that great.

330ml bottle, clear dark gold colour, riny mostly vanishing fizzy white head, hardly any lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and bisquit with light herbal hops and light cheesiness. Taste is initially balanced and gets sweetish and slightly acidic towards the middle turning into a slightly bitter finish. Light to medium body, slick mouthfeel, soft carbonation. A few notches above the cheap lagers, couldve been close to good Czech pils with a bit more hops in aroma and bitterness.

500ml bottle from Torfyanovka, Russia. Clear light yellow colour, large rocky moslty vanishing white head, fair lacing. Sweet lightly malty aroma of grain and meal with some traces of hops. Taste is initially sweetish and acidic, turning into a slightly bittter and moderately sweet abrupt finish with a slightly chalky feel. Light body, dry texture, lively carbonation. Light, dry and rather mineral waterish.

500ml bottle from Torfyanovka, Russia. Clear light yellow colour, medium frothy mostly lasting head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and bisquit with light floral hops with something of an ironlike smell upon opening. Taste is slightly acidic at first, then fairly sweet and has light hop bite in the somewhat mineral finish. Light to medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Fairly pleasant lager, not very interesting and rather underhopped though.

500ml bottle from a Supermarket right next to the Finnish border at Torfyanovka, Russia. Clear gold colour, small mostly lasting frothy white head, good lacing. Aroma of cooked corn and wet cardboard with light grainy malts with a little caramel and a bit of grassy hops. Taste is initially lightly bittersweet, gets a bit sweeter in the middle and turns into a moderately bitter finish. Light body, dry texture, lively carbonation. Aroma suggested below average nonalcoholic beer but taste was actually not too bad, a bit like a decent lager. Also looked good and mouthfeel was a bit too thin. A bit more interesting and refreshing than most NA lagers, probably better when drunk straight from the bottle while driving which was the original plan.

500ml can from supermarket in Kotka. Clear deep gold colour, medium mostly lasting frothy white head, fair lacing. Moderately hoppy aroma of orange, spruce and some floral hints with mild grainy and caramelly malts in the background. Taste is intially slightly sweet and acidic, turning into a moderately bitter longish finish with a slightly metallic hint. Medium body, dryish mouthfeel, lively carbonation. By far the tastiest brew from Olvi, still fairly modes for session IPA. Probably a good transition beer to more heavily hopped stuff.

330ml bottle, black colour, small mostly vanishing tan frothy head, little lacing. Moderately roasty aroma of coffee and chocolate and a bit of caramel with heavy citric and resiny hops and light fruity esters. Taste is initally moderately acidic and bitter with a hint of sweetness, turning into a heavily bitter long finish with a moderately astrigent feel. Full body, oily mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Quite tasty though a bit simple hop aroma albeit strong.

330ml bottle from gifted by a friend from Tartu. Black colour, medium mostly vanishing frothy light brown head, little lacing. Heavily malty and roasty aroma of coffee, chocolate, blackcurrant and plum along balancing herbal hops and light fruity esters. Intially moderately sweet taste, turning into a bittersweet finish with a moderately astrigent feel. Medium to full body, oily texture, average carbonation. Quite pleasant, perhaps not as intense as imperial stouts usually but an interesting and pleasant mix in any case.

355ml bottle from local supermarket in Helsinki, clear deep gold colour, small fizzy fully vanishing white head, hardly any lacing. Light malty aroma of grain and bisquit with a trace of grassy hops. Taste is initially balanced and mild with a hint of acidity, turning into a mildly bitter finish. Light body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Slightly maltier than the previous bulk lager from Mexico I tried but nowhere near interesting or tasty.

Pint can from local supermarket in Helsinki. Clear gold colour, medium mostly vanishing fizzy white head, little lacing. Sharp hoppy aroma of flowers and peppermint with some grain in the background. Taste is fairly balanced and finish mildly bittersweet however. Light to medium body, slick mouthfeel lively carbonation. Indeed, pretty much normal Karhu in the mouth with a major hop aroma of a hop variety that is better used for bittering. More interesting at least though not particularly pleasant.

330ml can, clear dark gold colour, medium frothy mostly vanishing white head marginal lacing. Medium to heavy malty aroma of grain and hay with mild floral hops and a fruity complexion. Taste is initially moderately sweet, turning into a mildly bitter and moderately sweet finish with an alcoholic feel. Medium to full body, oily mouthfeel average carbonation. Marginally less vomit-inducing than most booze-lagers.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Vyborg, made by Heineken Russia, hazy pale yellow colour, small frothy white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and bisquit with moderate banana esthers with some cloves and a hint of generic hops. Taste is moderately sweet at first, turning into a bittersweet finish wiht a hint of sourness. Medium body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Tolerable but unsurprising weizen, probably better price-quality ratio in Russia than with the bulk German wheat beers they sell at four times the price.

330ml can, clear light gold colour, small frothy mostly vanshing white head, fair lacing. Light malty aroma of hay and meal with light perfumey hops and some bubblegum and alcohol. Taste is initially crisp and balanced, turning into a moderately bitter finish. Light to medium body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Not a particularly great pilsener, still more bitterness than the normal bulk lagers in these parts, so would prefer it more than them.

0,33l can, clear gold colour, small frothy white mostly vanishing head, little lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and hay with light floral hops. Taste is initially slightly sweet and acidic, with light bitterness combined with the sweetness in the finish. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Not interesting at all and a bit underhopped even for a bulk lager, technically flawless as they usually are still.

500ml bottle from Mirbeer, st. Petersburg, abv 7.5%. Hazy dark amber colour, small offwhite mostly lasting frothy head, good lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and caramel with a bit of nuts, moderate blackcurranty and lemony hops. Taste is initally moderately sweet with a bit of acidity turning into a moderate to heavy bitter finish with a bit of sweetness. Full body, creamy texture, soft carbonation. Quite smooth for a double IPA, significant bitterness but not quite as heavy as usually. Using Czech hops made the aroma rather peculiar though fairly weak for compared to the intense smell I usually associate with this style. Far from unpleasant anyway and no noticeable alcohol either, so far from bad. Should probably pick up some other stuff from them the next time Im in st. Petersburg.
beer_name: AF Brew ABV not IBU: Kazbek

review_blob: 500ml bottle from Mirbeer, 4.9% abv. Clear copper colour, small off-white mostly lasting frothy head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of nuts, grain and caramel with light herbal hops and a hint of dark fruit. Taste is initially lightly sweet and acidic, turning into a bittersweet finish with a slightly astrigent feel. Medium body, oily mouthfeel, average carbonation. A very solid quality mrzen, a lot more depth in the aroma than many of the bulk German ones. Not the best of the style Ive had but in the top five certainly.

500ml bottle from somewhere in st. Petersburg. Clear gold colour, small fizzy mostly lasting white head, some lacing. Light malty aroma of hay and meal with some grasy hops. Taste is intially slightly sweet and turns into an abrupt marginally bittersweet finish wiht a somewhat carboady feel. Light body, slick mouthfeel, average carbonation. Quite tasteless although not downright offensive,.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Torfyanovka, clear gold colour, smalll white mostly vanishing frothy head, fair lacing. Heavily malty aroma of grain, caramel and hay, with a hint of hops and alcohol. Taste is initally slightly sweet and acidic, turning inot a moderately sweet and lightly bitter finish with a boozy feel. Medium body, oily texture, average carbonation. Tastes almost like a proper East-European booze-lager but still closer to the strength of generally drinkable beers. I suppose one could consider that a feat.

1 pint bottle from a supermarket in st. Petersburg. Clear copper colour, small frothy off-white mostly lasting head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of cereal, nuts and caramel with some earthy hops and fruity and somewhat leathery yeast esters. Taste is moderately sweet and slightly bitter first, turning into a lightly bittersweet finish with a slightly astigent feel. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, average carbonation. Certainly tastes like some kind of an amber ale, not very bitter though like english bitters. One of the more intersting brews from Baltika anyway and beats most Russian lagers. However far from awesome on the grand scale of things.

500ml bottle from Auchan near st. Petersbur, dark brown colour, riny fully vanishing beige head, no lacing. Moderately malty aroma of toast and rye bread with a hint of nuts, light floral hops and moderate banana with some bubblegum and cloves. Taste is initally slightly bitter and acidic, turning into a moderately bitter finish with an astrigent feel. Medium body, average carbonation, dry mouthfeel. Rather strange brew, reminds me of what I assume would turn out if using wheat beer yeast with barley malt and the same minimal amount of hops that is common in wheat beers. Far from undrinkable but not particularly pleasant either,

500ml bottle from Auchan on the outskirts of st. Petersburg. Slightly hazy golden colour, medium frothy white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain, bread and honey with light grassy hops. Taste is initally light sweet and acidic, turning into a shortish bitterseet finish, Medium to full body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Fairly nice lager with some character, lacks hops though.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Torfyanovka, clear dark copper colour, largish frothy off-white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of toast and caramel with some tarces of hops and bubble gum. Taste is initally moderately sweet and slightly acidic, turning into an abrupt bittersweet finish with a slightly astrigent feel. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Another one of them Russian kvass-beer hybrids and far from the tastier ones.

500ml bottle from Mirbeer, deep gold slightly hazy colour, small mostly vanishing white head, fair lacing. Heavily malty aroma of bread and caramel, moderate floral and herbal hops with a hint of fruitiness. Taste is initally quite sweet, turning into a moderately sweet finish with light bitterness. Medium to full body, oily mouthfeel, average carbonation. A very malty lager, quite high mashing temperature I suspect. It was a bit offbalance unfortunately even though there were noticeable hops in the aroma. More hops and couldve been seriously amazing, Body was incredibly full for a lager of this strength. Quite enjoyable, seems like it is possible to make decent and interesting beer in Russia.

500ml bottle from Auchan near st. Petersburg, clear gold colour, medium mostly lasting frothy head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain and bread with light floral hops and a hint of fruitiness. Taste is intially slightly bittersweet, turning into a moderate lightly bitter finsih. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. A fairly good helles, somewhat better even than a few German ones I had. Nothing insanely interesting still.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Torfyanovka, clear pale yellow colour, small frothy mostly vanishing white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty sweet aroma of hay and caramel with some butterscotch and a touch of floral hops. Taste is initially lightly sweet and acidic, turning into an abrupt sweet and sour finish with a little bitterness. Light to medium body, dry mouthfeel, lively carbonation. A bit more interesting than the stuff of this kind usually is mainly due to a small amount of yeast esthers.

500ml bottle from Mirbeer, st. Petersburg, clearish pale gold colour, small white frothy head, good lacing. Light malty aroma of bread and caramel, moderate to heavy tropical fruity and citrussy hops. Taste is intially mild bittersweet with a hint of acidity, turning into a moderately bitter finish. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, avereage carbonation. A very pleasant and refreshing ale, downright amazing for something obtainable for a bit over 100 roubles a bottle in Russia. Will get a case if I need to spend a longer time in st. Petersburg in the Summer.

500ml bottle from Auchan hypermarket in the outskirts of st. Petersburg, slightly hazy golden colour, medium frothy white head, good lacing. Heavily malty aroma of grain, bread and caramel, mild floral hops and a hint of butterscotch. Taste is slightly sweet first, turning into a lightly bitter finish. Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Fairly characterful and pleasant, although rather unbalanced on the malty side, reminds me a bit of many Lithuanian small breweries products.

500ml bottle from Auchan hypermarket on the outskirts of st. Petersburg, mainly acuired for a new country tick. Gloden colour with some largish chunks floating in it, medium frothy white head, fair lacing. Aroma is lactobacilli infection, sewage and vaginal discharge , oh my, never experienced this with a commercial brew. Taste is fairly vomit inducing, and somewhat sour, drainpour. Will re-rate if I find it again and if its from a batch not made on August 8th 2014.

500ml bottle from a convenience store in Torfyanovka, labelled as produced in Simrefpol, Russia, must be the firs somewhat politically charged beer I bought. Clear gold colour, medium fizzy white head, fair lacing. Sweetish moderately malty aroma of hay and cornmeal with light grassy hops. Taste is initially moderately sweet, turning into a mildly bittersweet finish with a chalky feel. Light body, lively carbonation, dry mouthfeel. A fairly unpleasant lager, among the worse ones I tried in Russia.

500ml bottle from Torfyanovka, clear gold colour, small fizzy White mostly vanishing head, little lacing.Light malty aroma of hay and meal with a bit of cardboard and no hops to speak of. Taste is initially mild and balanced with a hint of bitterness in the finish. Light body, moderate carbonation, dry mouthfeel. Quite a simple and exceptionally unhoppy light lager.

500ml bottle, black colour, tiny tan mostly vanishing frothy head, excellent lacing. Heavily malty roasty aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and plum with moderate herbal hops and some fruity esters. Taste is very smooth moderately sweet initially, turning into a long moderately bitter finish with an acetic feel and a hint of alcohol. Full body, creamy texture, average carbonation. Wonderfully intense experience and fairly unboozy for the strength

330ml bottle from Tartu, hazy gold colour, medium frothy white head, good lacing. Moderately malty and very sweet aroma of cookie, wheat and hay with moderate to heavy fruity yeast esters and some trace amounts of hops. Taste is initially a lot less sweet than the smell, spicy and fairly acidic, fairly long slightly bitter and sour finish, Medium body, slick mouthfeel, lively carbonation. Not the most complex of saisons Ive come across but quite enjoyable and not overly boring still.

330ml bottle from Tartu, clear gold colour, medium fizzy mostly vanishing white head, little lacing. Moderately malty aroma of grain, caramel and hay with moderate floral and herbal hops and a bit of alcohol, spiciness and peachy yeast esthers. Taste is initially slightly sweet, turning into a moderately bitter finish with a warming boozy feel. Medium to full body, oily texture, lively carbonation. Not a particularly amazing belgian ale, almost like it was between a strong lager and belgian trippel. Still a fair bit of aroma depth and far from offensive.

330ml bottle from Tartu, batch #12, 6,2% abv. Black colour, small creamyish lasting beige head, fair lacing. Moderately malty roasty aroma of plum, coffee and chocolate with light resiny hops and light leather. Taste is initially moderately sweet, lightly acidic with a hint of umami, moderately bitter finish with a moderately astigent feel. Medium to full body, average carbonation, oily mouthfeel. Quite a nice stout with a fair bit of character, possibly a bit too rosty but still not quite in the ashtray level.

355ml bottle from a licquor store in Tallinn, hazy orangeish gold colour, small frothy mostly vanishing white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of crain and cookie with heavy resiny, citric and earthy hops with a bit of tropical fruit. Taste is initally lightly sweet and acidic, turning quickly into a long heavily bitter finish. Medium to full body, slick mouthfeel, soft carbonation. Quie a solid IPA, fair bit above the average of the ones I tried.

330ml bottle, black colour, no head or lacing or carbonation. Roasty aroma of coffee, tobacco, leather and chocolate. Taste is rather sour with a fair bit of bitterness in the finish. Full body, oily texture, no carbonation. Infected and not overly pleasant, drainpour. Such luck to get a faulty bottle, probably not overly bad when not faulty.

500ml can from supermarket in Kotka, hazy dark amber colour, small fizzy mostly vanishing off-white head, fair lacing. Moderately malty aroma of cereal, toast and caramel, light floral hops some earthy notes. Taste is initially lightly sweet and acidic, turning into a lightly bittersweet and moderately long finish with a moderately astrigent feel. Light to medium body, somewhat watery texture, average carbonation. Some interestingish aromas but the taste and mouthfeel werent too great.

500ml bottle from supermarket in Vyborg, clear gold colour, medium fizzy mostly vanishing white head, fair lacing. Moderately to heavily malty aroma of bread and grain with light floral hops. Taste is initially lightly sweet and acidic, turning into a bittersweet finish with a slightly alcoholic feel. Medium body, slick texture, lively carbonation. A fair bit like a german helles, heavy maltiness and not much hops, good on east-european scale but nothing really outstanding and a bit boozy.
